"SECTION 1. FINDINGS." Summarized chunk:
The Congress finds that in 2005, the oil industry had significant revenues and profits, while multilateral development institutions provided billions in financing to the international oil and gas industry. Limited public resources should support the critical needs of developing countries, not the oil and gas industry. Providing financing to oil and gas operations overseas increases dependence on imported oil and gas, leading to poverty, economic inequality, poor governance, corruption, and conflict in developing countries. Countries rely on external debt for infrastructure in oil and gas projects, contributing to over one-third of global greenhouse gas emissions. Wealthy countries emit the majority of greenhouse gases, but the poorest nations will suffer the most from climate change. The World Bank Group recommended ending oil project financing by 2008 after evaluating their impact on poverty, local environments, and global climate. The Export-Import Bank is addressed in Section 2. The Export-Import Bank Act of 1945 is amended to prohibit financing for oil and gas projects. This includes a ban on guaranteeing, insuring, or extending credit for such projects or entities involved in them. The definition of an oil or gas project includes field development, processing facilities, pipelines, terminals, and other production or distribution operations. The Export-Import Bank Act of 1945 prohibits financing for oil and gas projects, including field development, processing facilities, pipelines, terminals, and other production or distribution operations. The Export-Import Bank Act of 1945 prohibits financing for oil and gas projects, including field development, processing facilities, pipelines, terminals, and other production or distribution operations. SEC. 3. OVERSEAS PRIVATE INVESTMENT CORPORATION. Section 237 of the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 is amended to restrict insurance and financing for oil and gas projects, both directly and indirectly. This includes prohibiting the Overseas Private Investment Corporation from providing insurance, reinsurance, guarantees, or financing for such projects. The Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 is amended to restrict insurance and financing for oil and gas projects, including prohibiting the Overseas Private Investment Corporation from providing any form of financing to such projects. The term 'oil or gas project' is defined as various operations related to oil and gas production or distribution. SEC. 1626 of the International Financial Institutions Act prohibits assistance for oil or gas projects. The Secretary of the Treasury is directed to oppose any assistance from multilateral development institutions to oil and gas projects. Assistance includes grants, loans, credit extensions, technical support, guarantees, and other forms of financial backing. Annual reports on this matter must be submitted to Congress by June 1 each year. The Secretary of the Treasury must report to Congress annually by June 1 on assistance provided by multilateral development institutions to oil and gas projects, including financial and sectoral lending to the energy sector. SEC. 5. REPORT ON UNITED STATES ASSISTANCE TO SUPPORT THE OIL AND GAS SECTORS OF DEVELOPING COUNTRIES. The Administrator of the United States Agency for International Development must submit a report to Congress within 180 days detailing assistance provided to developing countries' oil and gas sectors in fiscal year 2007. The report will list recipient countries and specify the type and amount of assistance given. SEC. 6. The President will notify the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development that the US policy is for member states to prohibit export credit agencies from funding oil or gas projects. SEC. 7. A study on energy sector lending will be conducted. The Comptroller General of the United States will submit a report on financing and assistance to the energy sector by various institutions, analyzing the impact on greenhouse gas emissions. The Comptroller General of the United States will submit a report analyzing the environmental impacts and energy provision to impoverished populations facilitated by financing and assistance to the energy sector. SEC. 8. DEFINITIONS. The term "assistance" includes grants, loans, credit extensions, technical support, guarantees, insurance, and reinsurance. The term "oil or gas project" refers to field development, processing facilities, pipelines, terminals, and other production or distribution operations.
